options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: C. This lines the layer of choriocapillaris
questions.explanation:
Solution:

This lines the layer of choriocapillaris Basal lamina of choroid . It is also called Bruch's membrane and lines the layer of choriocapillaris. It l ies in approximation with the pigment epithelium of the retina. Choroid Anatomy CHOROID: Choroid is the posterior-most part of the vascular coat of the eyeball . It extends from the optic disc to the ora serrata. Its inner surface is smooth and brown and lies in contact with the pigment epithelium of the retina . The outer surface is rough and lies in contact with the sclera .

Highyeild:

Microscopic structure: 1 . Suprachoroidal lamina. It is a thin membrane of condensed collagen fibers, melanocytes, and fibroblasts. It is continuous anteriorly with the supraciliary lamina. The potential space between the membrane Sclera and sclera is called suprachoroidal space, which contains long and short posterior ciliary arteries and nerves. Stroma of the choroid . It consists of loose collagenous tissue with some elastic and reticular fibers. It also contains pigment cells and plasma cells. Its main bulk is formed by vessels which are arranged in three layers. (i) layer of large vessels (Haller's layer), (ii) layer of medium vessels (Sattler's layer), and (iii) layer of the choriocapillaris, which nourishes the outer layers of the retina. 3. Basal lamina. It is also called Bruch's membrane and lines the layer of choriocapillaris . It lies in approximation with the pigment epithelium of the retina.

questions.text: In the Ciliary zone of the iris, a series of radial streaks are present due to which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Underlying radial blood vessels and crypts are depressions where the superficial layer of the iris is missing.

options.label: B
options.text: Underlying longitudinal blood vessels and crypts are depressions where the superficial layer of the iris is denser.

options.label: C
options.text: Underlying radial blood vessels and crypts are depressions where the superficial layer of the iris is denser.

options.label: D
options.text: Underlying loose connective tissue and crypts are depressions where the superficial layer of the iris is missing.

questions.correct_answer: A. Underlying radial blood vessels and crypts are depressions where the superficial layer of the iris is missing.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Underlying radial blood vessels and crypts are depressions where the superficial layer of the iris is missing. Ciliary zone - It presents a series of radial streaks due to underlying radial blood vessels and crypts, depressions where a superficial layer of the iris is missing. Crypts are arranged in two rows —the peripheral present near the iris root and the central present near the collarette. ANATOMY OF IRIS- IRIS Iris is the anterior-most part of the uveal tract . It is a thin circular disc corresponding to the diaphragm of a camera. In its center is an aperture of about 4 mm diameter called a pupil, which regulates the amount of light reaching the retina . At the periphery, the iris is attached to the middle of the anterior surface of the ciliary body. It divides the space between the cornea and lens into anterior and posterior chambers.

Highyeild:

Macroscopic appearance The anterior surface of the iris can be divided into a ciliary zone and a pupillary zone by a zigzag line called a collarette. Ciliary zone. It presents a series of radial streaks due to underlying radial blood vessels and crypts, depressions where a superficial layer of the iris is missing. Crypts are arranged in two rows-the peripheral present near the iris root and the central present near the collarette. Pupillary zone. This part of the iris lies between the collarette and pigmented pupillary frill and is relatively smooth and flat.

Radial and not longitudinal and Missing, not dense . Option: C. Underlying radial blood vessels and crypts are depressions where the superficial layer of the iris is more dense. - missing and not dense Option: D. Underlying loose connective tissue and crypts are depressions where a superficial layer of the iris is missing. - blood vessels and not loose connective tissue.

Extraedge:

Microscopic structure The iris consists of four layers which, from anterior to posterior, are : Anterior limiting layer. It is the anterior-most condensed part of the stroma. It consists of melanocytes and fibroblasts. Previously, this layer was called the endothelial layer of the iris, which was a misnomer. This layer is deficient in the areas of crypts. The definitive colour of the iris depends on this layer. In the blue iris, this layer is thin and contains few pigment cells. While in the brown iris, it is Thick and densely pigmented. Iris stroma . It consists of loosely arranged collagenous networks that embed the sphincter pupillae muscle, dilator pupillae muscle, vessels, nerves, pigment cells, and other cells, including lymphocytes, fibroblasts, macrophages, and mast cells. Sphincter pupillae muscle forms a one-millimeter broad circular band in the pupillary part of the iris. Parasympathetic fibers supply it through the third nerve. It constricts the pupil. Dilator pupillae muscle lies in the posterior part of the stroma of the ciliary zone of the Its myofilaments are located in the outer part of the cells of the anterior pigment epithelial layer. Cervical sympathetic nerves supply it and dilate the pupil. Anterior pigmented epithelial layer . It is the anterior continuation of the pigment epithelium of the retina. and ciliary body. This layer gives rise to the dilator pupillae muscle. Posterior pigmented epithelial layer . It is the anterior continuation of the non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary body. At the pupillary margin, it forms the pigmented frill and becomes continuous with the anterior pigmented epithelial layer.

questions.correct_answer: C. Iris nerves are usually myelinated; however, Schwann cells find all nerves enclosed.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Iris nerves are usually myelinated; however, Schwann cells find all nerves enclosed. The sphincter pupillae muscle forms a one-millimeter broad circular band in the pupillary part of the iris. It is supplied by parasympathetic fibres through the third nerve. It constricts the pupil. The dilator pupillae muscle lies in the posterior part of the stroma of the ciliary zone of the iris.

Highyeild:

Its myofilaments are in the outer part of the cells of the anterior pigment epithelial layer . It is supplied by cervical sympathetic nerves and dilates the pupil.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . The sphincter pupillae retains its function even if severed radially because of its unique distribution of fibres. Option: B . Nerves in iris stroma: Iris nerves are usually unmyelinated; however, some nerves are found to be enclosed by Schwann cells. Option: D . Pigment dispersion syndrome: Pigment dispersion syndrome is a bilateral condition characterized by the liberation of pigment granules from the iris pigment epithelium. It is caused by the mechanical rubbing of the posterior pigment layer of the iris against lens zonules as a result of excessive posterior bowing of the mid-peripheral portion of the iris. However, the pigment epithelium itself may be abnormally susceptible to pigment shedding.

questions.text: A 40 year female patient presented with pulsatile exophthalmos along with proptosis, chemosis, bruit, and progressive dimness of vision. On examination, it shows orbital edema, extraocular muscles are enlarged and ruptured ICH and raised intracranial pressure. Which blood vessels show enlargement in CT?

options.label: A
options.text: Superior Ophthalmic Vein

options.label: B
options.text: Inferior ophthalmic vein

options.label: C
options.text: Minor arterial circle

options.label: D
options.text: Major arterial circle

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superior Ophthalmic Vein Carotico-cavernous fistula -> raised episcleral venous pressure due to A-V fistula , e., ICA to cavernous sinus -> enlargement of the superior ophthalmic vein. CAROTID-CAVERNOUS FISTULA Carotid-cavernous fistula is an acquired abnormal communication between the carotid arterial system and the venous cavernous sinus . Clinical types There are two types of carotid-cavernous fistula: High-flow fistula is secondary to trauma or iatrogenic and presents acutely with pain and proptosis (often pulsatile exophthalmos). Chemosis, congestion, bruit, ophthalmoplegia (nerve palsies), headache, and objective pulsatile tinnitus. The classical triad of presentation is proptosis, chemosis, and bruit . It presents within days or weeks following trauma. Low-flow fistula: These develop spontaneously in elderly women, during pregnancy, or in those with hyperplastic tissue. These typically present slowly with less pronounced symptoms.

Highyeild:

Differential diagnosis Common causes of proptosis after trauma are: • Carotid-cavernous fistula • Retro-orbital haematoma • Superior orbital fissure syndrome • Orbital apex syndrome. The differentiating feature of CCF from other conditions is the presence of conjunctival congestion and chemosis.

Extraedge:

Investigations Selective carotid angiography using the digital subtraction technique is the investigation of choice and is essential if the treatment is contemplated. Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is also commonly used. Treatment A carotid-cavernous fistula requires a definitive treatment, which currently involves endovascular technique. The fistula can usually be occluded with a balloon or coil without sacrificing the carotid artery.
